choices.text: Heavy infection is associated with Rectal prolapse
Fertilised unembronated egg takes time to infect after it goes in soil
Can spread to lungs and cause Asthma like symptoms

questions.text: Which of the following options is wrong about ascaris lumbricoides? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Heavy infection is associated with Rectal prolapse

 

Heavy infection with rectal prolapse is NOT associated with Ascaris lumbricoides infection. This clinical manifestation is actually characteristic of Trichuris trichiura (whipworm) infection. 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Most infections are asymptomatic: Most Ascaris infections are indeed asymptomatic, particularly in immunocompetent individuals. This is an important clinical feature of ascariasis.

 

Option C. Fertilised unembronated egg takes time to infect after it goes in soil: Ascaris eggs can be either embryonated or unembryonated. The unembryonated eggs require time in soil to develop and become infective. 

 

Option D. Can spread to lungs and cause Asthma like symptoms: Ascaris larvae migrate through the lungs as part of their life cycle (pulmonary phase). During this migration, they can cause respiratory symptoms including cough, wheezing, and asthma-like symptoms, known as Löffler's syndrome.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Rectal prolapse is a characteristic complication of heavy Trichuris trichiura (whipworm) infection, not Ascaris lumbricoides infection. Ascaris causes pulmonary symptoms during its larval migration phase and is often asymptomatic in its intestinal phase.

questions.text: The transfer of genetic information between DNA molecules inside a cell is called: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Transposition

 

Explanation:

 

Transposition is the correct answer because it refers to the movement of DNA segments called transposons ("jumping genes") between different DNA molecules within the same cell. Transposons are discrete segments of DNA that can move from one location to another in a "cut-and-paste" manner between chromosomal and extrachromosomal DNA molecules inside a bacterial cell.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Transformation - This is the transfer of genetic information through free or naked DNA from the environment into a bacterial cell. It involves uptake of external DNA, not transfer between DNA molecules already inside a cell.

 

Option C. Conjugation - This involves the transfer of genetic material from one bacterium (donor or male) to another (recipient or female) through direct physical contact (through a sex pilus). It is a process of transfer between different cells, not between DNA molecules inside the same cell.

 

Option D. Duplication - This refers to the replication of DNA during cell division, where the entire DNA molecule is copied. It does not involve transfer of genetic segments between different DNA molecules.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Transposons (mobile genetic elements) facilitate genetic diversity within a cell by moving DNA segments between chromosomal and plasmid DNA. This mechanism of transposition can lead to the acquisition of new characteristics by bacteria, including antibiotic resistance.

questions.text: Which of the following is called as Australia antigen? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) HBsAg

 

HBsAg (Hepatitis B surface antigen) is also known as the Australia antigen. It is called so because it was first isolated from the serum of an Australian person.

 

Sera from hepatitis B patients when observed under an electron microscope show three types of particles:

 

  • A spherical particle: 22nm, most abundant, contains only HBsAg.
  • Filamentous or tubular particle: 22m, contains only HBsAg.
  • A double-walled spherical structure: 42m diameter, is the complete Hepatitis B virus. It was described by Dane and is called Dane particle.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. HBeAg: Incorrect, as HBeAg is a Hepatitis B envelope antigen associated with the virus's replication and infectivity but not known as the Australia antigen.

 

Option C. HBcAg: Incorrect, HBcAg or Hepatitis B core antigen is associated with the core of the virus but is not referred to as the Australia antigen.

 

Option D. HBV-DNA: Incorrect, this refers to the genetic material of the Hepatitis B virus itself and is not synonymous with the Australia antigen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

HBsAg, also known as the Australia antigen, plays a pivotal role in the diagnosis and monitoring of Hepatitis B infection. Its presence in the blood typically indicates an active Hepatitis B infection.

questions.text: A patient presented with complaints of persistent cough and weight loss. He had a history of contact with multiple sexual partners. He was diagnosed as HIV positive 6 months back and is poorly adherent to his medications. The fungal culture of sputum was negative. On Gomori methamine silver staining, the cells showed darkly stained crescent-shaped cysts. What is the most likely causative organism? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pneumocystis jerovecii

 

The given scenario is pointing out to pneumonia caused by Pneumocystis jirovecii.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Paracoccidioides brasiliensis causes paracoccidioidomycosis (aka South American blastomycosis • Lutz-Splendore-de Almeida disease), presents with oral mucosa lesions, cervical lymphadenopathy, and pulmonary lesions.

 

 

Option B. Histoplasma capsulatum causes histoplasmosis, systemic granulomatous disease. On GMS staining, shows tiny oval yeast cells (2–4 µm size) with narrow-based budding within the macrophages with an underlying granulomatous response.

 

 

Option C. Coccidioides immitis causes coccidioidomycosis, around 60% patients are asymptomatic. Manifests as pneumonia, cavities, pleural effusion or nodule formation, Skin lesions, Arthritis.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PCP) is a critical opportunistic infection in HIV/AIDS patients, characterized by non-specific respiratory symptoms and distinctive cystic structures on Gomori methenamine silver staining. Regular prophylaxis and monitoring are essential for at-risk populations.

questions.text: What is the infective dose range for Salmonella Typhi? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 10² to 10⁵ bacilli

 

Explanation:

 

The infective dose for Salmonella Typhi falls within the range of 10² to 10⁵ bacilli. This is a relatively low infectious dose compared to many other enteric pathogens, which explains why typhoid fever can be transmitted through contaminated food or water even with modest bacterial loads.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. One bacillus: This is incorrect because a single bacterial cell of S. Typhi is insufficient to cause infection. Even highly virulent pathogens typically require multiple organisms to establish infection and overcome host defenses.

 

Option B. 1 to 10 bacilli: This is incorrect because this range is too low for S. Typhi to establish infection. While S. Typhi has a relatively low infectious dose, it still requires more than 10 organisms.

 

Option D. 10⁸ to 10¹⁰ bacilli: This is incorrect because this range is too high. Such a high bacterial load would be required for organisms with low pathogenicity, unlike S. Typhi which can cause infection with a much lower dose (10² to 10⁵).

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Salmonella Typhi has a moderate infectious dose requirement (10² to 10⁵ bacilli), which contributes to its efficiency as a pathogen and explains why typhoid fever can spread relatively easily through contaminated water and food supplies.

questions.text: In the case of an elderly male presenting with meningitis, a gram stain of the CSF sample shows the presence of gram-positive bacilli. Which of the following statements accurately pertains to the motility of the responsible microorganism? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Motile at 25° C, non-motile at 37°C

 

  • The provided case involves an elderly man with meningitis, and the smear analysis indicates the presence of a gram-positive bacillus, strongly indicative of a Listeria infection. Listeria exhibits motility at 25°C but loses its ability to move at 37°C.

 

LAB DIAGNOSIS OF LISTERIA MONOCYTOGENES

 

  • Motility: shows differential motility, which is due to temperature dependent flagella expression) 
    • Tumbling type of motility at 25°C
    • Non-Motile at 37°C
  • Culture → Blood agar, Chocolate agar
  • Selective media → PALCAM agar

 

TREATMENT

 

  • Meningitis → DOC → Ampicillin in combination with gentamicin for synergistic effect
  • Penicillin allergy → Cotrimoxazole
  • In febrile gastroenteritis → Amoxicillin

 

Educational Objective:

 

Listeria monocytogenes exhibits motility at 25°C but is non-motile at 37°C.

questions.text: The disruption of which of the following is responsible for watery diarrhea in cholera caused by Vibrio? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Zonula occludens

 

When cholera toxin is released from the bacteria in the infected intestine, it binds to the intestinal cells known as enterocytes through the interaction of the pentameric B subunit of the toxin with the GM1 ganglioside receptor on the intestinal cell, triggering endocytosis of the toxin.

 

Next, the A/B cholera toxin must undergo cleavage of the A1 domain from the A2 domain in order for A1 to become an active enzyme.

 

Once inside the enterocyte, the enzymatic A1 fragment of the toxin A subunit enters the cytosol, where it activates the G protein Gsa through an ADP-ribosylation reaction that acts to lock the G protein in its GTP-bound form, thereby continually stimulating adenylate cyclase to produce cAMP. 

 

The high cAMP levels activate the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR), causing a dramatic efflux of ions and water from infected enterocytes, leading to watery diarrhea.

 

 

The effects of cholera involve the actions of other Vibrio cholerae toxins that aid the pathogen in its colonization, coordinated expression of virulence factors, and toxin action.

 

These additional proteins include

 

  • Zona occludens toxin (zot, involved in Vibrio cholerae invasion by acting to decrease intestinal tissue resistance)
  • Accessory cholera toxin (ace, increases fluid secretion)
  • Toxin-coregulated pilus (tcpA, essential colonisation factor receptor for the CTXf phage)
  • NAG-specific heat-labile toxin (st)
  • Outer membrane porin proteins (ompU and ompT).
  • The expression of virulence factors is controlled by the transcriptional factors ToxR, TcpP and ToxT.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intercalated discs: Found in cardiac muscle cells and involved in cell-to-cell adhesion and electrical coupling, not related to intestinal fluid secretion.

 

Option B. Macula densa: Involved in regulating kidney function and blood pressure, not related to intestinal fluid secretion.

 

Option D. Hemidesmosomes: Involved in cell-to-extracellular matrix adhesion, not related to intestinal fluid secretion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The disruption of zonula occludens (tight junctions) by cholera toxin is responsible for the increased permeability of intestinal epithelial cells, leading to the characteristic watery diarrhea seen in cholera.

questions.text: A patient presented with case of diarrhea after eating sea food/ oyster, showing Kanagawa phenomenon. What is the causative organism? (FMGE July 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vibrio parahemolyticus

 

Explanation:

 

Vibrio parahemolyticus causes Food-borne gastroenteritis

 

  • MC presentation
  • Following uncooked sea food (e.g. Oyster and shellfish) intake.
  • Watery diarrhea (MC), dysentery, abdominal cramps.
  • Extraintestinal manifestations → wound infection, otitis and sepsis.

 

 

Bipolar staining – safety pin appearance is seen in 5 bacteria’s –

 

Mnemonic

 

 

Note - Kanagawa phenomenon

 

  • V. parahaemolyticus  produce Beta  hemolysis on special blood agar medium → called the Wagatsuma agar
  • Wagatsuma agar  → High-salt (7%) blood agar (defibrinated human or rabbit blood) medium containing d-mannitol as the carbohydrate source.
  • Hemolysis observed on Wagatsuma agar medium, referred to as the Kanagawa phenomenon (KP).

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vibrio cholera: Causes cholera, characterized by severe watery diarrhea but not typically associated with the Kanagawa phenomenon.

 

Option C. E. coli: Can cause gastroenteritis but is not associated with the Kanagawa phenomenon.

 

Option D. Vibrio vulnificus: Can cause severe infections from seafood consumption but is not typically associated with the Kanagawa phenomenon.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vibrio parahemolyticus is the causative organism of gastroenteritis following the consumption of uncooked seafood, identified by the Kanagawa phenomenon. The most common symptoms are watery diarrhea, dysentery, and abdominal cramps.

 

Additional Information -

 

Classification based on Salt Requirement

 

1. Nonhalophilic vibrios:

  • Can grow without salt but 1% salt is optimum for their growth.
  • Cannot grow at higher salt concentrations.
  • Examples → V. cholerae and V. mimicus

 

2. Halophilic vibrios: 

  • Cannot grow in the absence of salt.
  • Can tolerate and grow at higher salt concentration of up to 7–10%.  Examples  → V.   parahaemolyticus, V. alginolyticus and V. vulnificus.

questions.text: A patient with crushed limb after amputation developed crepitus. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Gas gangrene

 

Explanation:

 

  1.  The patient had a crushed limb that required amputation.
  2. After the amputation, the patient developed crepitus, which refers to the presence of gas bubbles in the tissues.
  3. The development of crepitus after an injury or amputation suggests a gas-forming bacterial infection, specifically gas gangrene.
  4. Gas gangrene is caused by the bacteria Clostridium species, primarily Clostridium perfringens, which can contaminate wounds from soil or other environmental sources.
  5. Clostridium perfringens is a gas-forming bacteria that ferments sugars (such as glucose in the body) into acid and gas, leading to tissue necrosis and the formation of gas bubbles (crepitus) in the gangrenous tissue.

 

The presence of crepitus, along with the history of a crushed limb and amputation, strongly suggests gas gangrene as the diagnosis.

 

Established agents:

 

  • C. perfringens
  • C. novyi
  • C. septicum

 

Probable agents: C. histolyticum, C. sporogenes, C. fallax, C. bifermentans, C. sordellii, C. aerofoetidum, and C. tertium.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cellulitis: This is a bacterial skin infection characterized by redness, swelling, and warmth, but it does not typically involve the formation of gas bubbles.

 

Option B. Necrotizing fasciitis: This is a severe bacterial infection of the fascia (connective tissue) that can lead to tissue necrosis, but it is not specifically associated with the formation of gas bubbles.

 

Option C. Folliculitis: This is an infection of the hair follicles, which is unlikely to occur after an amputation and does not involve gas formation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gas gangrene is a potentially life-threatening infection caused by gas-forming Clostridium species, primarily Clostridium perfringens. It is characterized by the formation of gas bubbles (crepitus) in the necrotic and gangrenous tissues, typically occurring after traumatic injuries or surgical procedures that allow the contamination of wounds with soil or environmental sources.

questions.text: Cowdry Type A inclusions are seen in? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Herpes simplex

 

Cowdry type A inclusions are seen in the vesicles of Herpes Simplex infection

 

The classic Cowdry type A inclusion appears as a light purple, homogeneous intranuclear structure surrounded by a clear halo. The inclusions stain with antibodies to HS, permitting a rapid, specific diagnosis of HSV infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rabies: Incorrect, as Rabies is associated with Negri bodies, which are specific cytoplasmic inclusions.

 

Option C. Molluscum contagiosum: Incorrect, as this condition is linked to Henderson-Peterson bodies, which are intracytoplasmic inclusions.

 

Option D. Adenovirus: Incorrect for Cowdry Type A inclusions; however, Cowdry type C basophilic inclusions are seen in Adenovirus infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inclusion bodies produced in viral infection:

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl presents with severe headache, photophobia and high fever of 101°F. On examination, papilledema and nuchal rigidity was present. Kernig's and Brudzinski signs were positive. CS examination shows reduced glucose, increased protein, and increased leukocytes with the predominance of neutrophils. Gram staining of the CSF is shown below. What is the Causative organism? (FMGE DECEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Neisseria meningitidis

 

History and physical examination findings are suggestive of bacterial meningitis. The given image shows intracellular gram-negative diplococci i.e., Neisseria meningitidis

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Haemophilus influenzae type B: This organism can cause bacterial meningitis, particularly in unvaccinated children, but it typically appears as small, pleomorphic gram-negative coccobacilli on Gram stain.

 

Option C. Streptococcus pneumonia: This is another common cause of bacterial meningitis and would appear as gram-positive lancet-shaped diplococci on Gram stain.

 

Option D. Listeria monocytogenes: This organism can cause meningitis, particularly in neonates, the elderly, and immunocompromised individuals, and appears as gram-positive bacilli on Gram stain

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: The Kanagawa phenomenon, demonstrated using Wagatsuma agar, is characteristic of which bacterial organism? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vibrio parahaemolyticus

 

The Kanagawa phenomenon refers to beta-hemolysis observed on Wagatsuma agar medium, which is specifically associated with Vibrio parahaemolyticus. Wagatsuma agar is a specialized high-salt (7%) blood agar medium that contains defibrinated human or rabbit blood with D-mannitol as the carbohydrate source. When V. parahaemolyticus is cultured on this medium, it produces enhanced beta-hemolysis due to the thermostable direct hemolysin (TDH) toxin. This phenomenon is used as a diagnostic tool to identify pathogenic strains of V. parahaemolyticus, particularly those causing gastroenteritis following consumption of contaminated seafood.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vibrio cholerae: This organism does not show the Kanagawa phenomenon. V. cholerae is a halophilic vibrio that grows on TCBS agar as yellow colonies (sucrose fermenter) and is responsible for cholera, but it does not produce the specific hemolysis seen in Wagatsuma agar.

 

Option C. Shigella sonnei: This is an enterobacteria that causes dysentery and does not show any specific hemolysis on Wagatsuma agar. Shigella species are non-motile, non-lactose fermenting gram-negative bacilli that are diagnosed through different methods.

 

Option D. Burkholderia pseudomallei: This organism causes melioidosis and is not associated with the Kanagawa phenomenon. It is a gram-negative bacillus that has different biochemical characteristics and is not related to the Wagatsuma agar test.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Kanagawa phenomenon is specific to Vibrio parahaemolyticus and involves beta-hemolysis on Wagatsuma agar (high-salt blood agar with human/rabbit blood and D-mannitol).

questions.text: In a 30-year-old female from a tribal area who presents with fever for the last 3 days, which of the following is the most likely causative agent of her illness based on the diagnosis of malaria made through examination of the peripheral smear? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) P. falciparum

 

The image shows ring forms/ early trophozoites in erythrocyte, which are binucleate (double chromatin) resembling stereo headphones in appearance, characteristic of P. falciparum.

 

There may be several rings present within a single erythrocyte. The rings are often attached to the margins of the red cells and are described as form applique or accole.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. P. malariae: Causes quartan malaria with a longer incubation period and typically presents with band-form trophozoites across the red cells, distinct from the forms seen in P. falciparum.

 

Option C. P. ovale: Known for causing tertian malaria with similar clinical presentations to P. vivax, including the presence of Schüffner's dots and slightly enlarged and ovale-shaped erythrocytes.

 

Option D. P. vivax: Also causes tertian malaria, characterized by Schüffner's stippling in erythrocytes, larger ring forms than P. falciparum, and less severe disease outcomes compared to P. falciparum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Identification of P. falciparum through the presence of distinctive ring forms in red blood cells on a peripheral smear is crucial for rapid initiation of appropriate antimalarial therapy, particularly in endemic regions. Early treatment is vital to prevent severe complications and reduce the morbidity and mortality associated with this malaria species.

questions.text: A 47-year-old renal transplant patient presented with watery diarrhea. Stool examination revealed oval cysts 30 x 15 microns as shown in the image below. Which among the following is the causative organism:  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Isospora

 

In this case, the patient is a renal transplant recipient, indicating an immunocompromised state due to immunosuppressive drugs. Immunocompromised patients are more susceptible to infections, including parasitic infections causing diarrhea.

 

The stool examination revealed oval cysts measuring 30 x 15 microns, which were acid-fast positive. These characteristics are crucial in identifying the parasite:

 

  1. Immunocompromised State: This condition makes the patient more prone to infections by opportunistic parasites.
  2. Acid-Fast Positive Cysts: This staining characteristic is seen in certain parasitic cysts.
  3. Size and Shape of Cysts: The cysts are oval and measure 30 x 15 microns.

 

Based on the provided images and reference notes, Isospora belli (now known as Cystoisospora belli) is the parasite that fits these criteria. Isospora cysts are known to be oval in shape and measure approximately 20 to 30 microns in length, consistent with the 30 x 15 microns cysts described in the question.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cryptosporidium: Cryptosporidium cysts are round, not oval, and are much smaller (4 to 6 microns). They do not fit the size and shape described in this case.

 

Option C. Cyclospora: Cyclospora cysts are also round and measure approximately 8 to 10 microns, which do not match the size and shape given in the question.

 

Option D. Microsporidia: Microsporidia produce very small spores (1 to 2 microns) and are not typically described as having 30 x 15 microns cysts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Isospora belli (Cystoisospora belli) causes watery diarrhea in immunocompromised patients and is identified by its oval cysts measuring approximately 20 to 30 microns, which are acid-fast positive.

questions.text: A female patient presents with complaints of thick white vaginal secretions. Which of the following can be used to identify the likely species of the causative agent? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) CHROMagar

 

The clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of candidiasis. CHROMagar can be used for the rapid identification of Candida species. It is based on the fungal enzymatic action on various chromogenic substrates in the medium.

 

After incubation on CHROMagar for 1-4 days, colonies are seen: Candida albicans colonies appear green.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bird seed agar: Mainly used for the isolation and differentiation of Cryptococcus neoformans due to its ability to produce brown colonies owing to phenol oxidase activity.

 

Option B. Brain heart infusion agar: A rich, non-selective medium used for cultivating a variety of fastidious organisms, not specific for differentiating Candida species.

 

Option D. Sabouraud dextrose agar: Commonly used for the culture of fungi but does not differentiate between Candida species as effectively as CHROMagar.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CHROMagar is the preferred medium for rapidly identifying and differentiating various Candida species directly from clinical specimens like vaginal swabs, with Candida albicans typically forming green colonies on this medium. This tool is essential for quick, accurate diagnosis and appropriate treatment of candidiasis.

choices.text: Methylene blue - malachite green - acetic acid-water

questions.text: A 32-year-old laborer working at a construction site presented with fever and hemoptysis. The sputum sample collected for examination showed the following. The smear will be stained by which of the following sequences? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Carbol fuschin - acid-alcohol - methylene blue

 

Clinical history along with microscopic picture is suggestive of mycobacterium tuberculosis infection. Microphotograph is of TB bacillus, Mycobacterium tuberculosis on an oil-immersion smear slide stained with Ziehl-Neelsen or acid-fast staining of a clinical sample. Bacilli are long and rod-shaped; a bacillus is indicated by a black arrow. Acid-fast bacilli are bright red after staining.

 

The Ziehl-Neelsen staining technique is a differential staining technique that was initially developed by Ziehl and modified later by Neelsen, hence the name Ziehl-Neelsen stain.

 

Reagent used in Ziehl Neelson stain are-

 

  • Carbol-Fuschin (Primary dye)
  • 20% sulphuric acid or acid-alcohol (Decolorizer)
  • Methylene Blue dye (counterstain) or malachite green

 

The use of acid-alcohol in the technique earned it the name Acid-Fast Stain and the application of heat in the technique gives it the name the hot method of Acid-Fast staining

 

Mycobacterium, Nocardia, Isospora, Cryptosporidium, and some fungi contain a thick cell wall made up of lipoidal complexes known as mycolic acid.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gentian violet - iodine - alcohol - safranin: This sequence is used for Gram staining, not for acid-fast bacilli.

 

Option B. Methylene blue - malachite green - acetic acid - water: This sequence is not used for any standard bacterial staining protocol.

 

Option C. Methanol - methylene blue - acid - water: This sequence does not correspond to the Ziehl-Neelsen stain or any other standard staining protocol for acid-fast bacilli.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Ziehl-Neelsen staining method, involving carbol fuschin, acid-alcohol, and methylene blue, is used to identify Mycobacterium tuberculosis in clinical samples. This technique highlights acid-fast bacilli, which retain the red color of carbol fuschin even after decolorization with acid-alcohol.

questions.text: A female patient presented with symptomatic urinary symptoms. On laboratory examination, growth of coagulase negative novobiocin-resistant Staphylococcus with >10⁴ colony growth is seen. What is the true statement regarding this? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Consider it as a UTI


The patient has symptomatic urinary symptoms, and the laboratory findings indicate the presence of coagulase-negative, novobiocin-resistant Staphylococcus with a colony count greater than 10⁴. These characteristics point towards a urinary tract infection (UTI) caused by Staphylococcus saprophyticus, which is known to be novobiocin-resistant and commonly implicated in UTIs, particularly in females. Since the patient is symptomatic, it is important to treat this condition as a UTI rather than dismissing or labeling it as contamination.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Take 3 consecutive urine samples: This option is incorrect because taking 3 consecutive urine samples is usually required for parasitic infections, where organisms are intermittently shed in the urine. For bacterial infections like this one, particularly with a significant growth of a specific organism, this is unnecessary.

 

Option B. No treatment required: This is incorrect as the patient is symptomatic. In symptomatic UTIs, especially with a significant colony count of a known pathogenic organism, treatment is essential. Leaving a symptomatic patient without treatment could lead to worsening of symptoms and complications.

 

Option C. It is a contaminated sample: This is incorrect because contamination is typically suggested when there are multiple types of organisms present or a mix of non-pathogenic flora. In this case, the growth of coagulase-negative, novobiocin-resistant Staphylococcus is specific and significant, aligning with clinical symptoms, ruling out contamination.

 

Educational Objective:


When a female patient presents with symptomatic urinary symptoms and lab findings show coagulase-negative, novobiocin-resistant Staphylococcus with significant colony growth, it should be considered as a UTI and treated accordingly.

questions.text: A patient is suffering from fever and he is diagnosed with condition caused by a lactose fermenting bacteria, he is advised for culture, Which culture media is used to differentiate lactose and non-lactose fermenter? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mac conkey agar

 

Culture media is used to differentiate lactose and non-lactose fermenter - MacConkey agar

 

It is used to distinguish lactose fermenters from non-lactose fermenters

 

it is a selective and differential culture medium

 

Contents of MacConkey agar: Peptone, Lactose, Agar, Sodium Taurocholate

 

 

Lactose fermenters seen as pink colonies, non-lactose fermenters seen as colorless or pale.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bile salt agar: Incorrect. Bile salt agar is primarily used for the isolation of enteric pathogens, particularly Salmonella and Shigella, but it does not differentiate lactose fermenters from non-lactose fermenters

 

Option C. LJ media: Incorrect. Lowenstein-Jensen (LJ) media is used for the culture of Mycobacterium tuberculosis. It does not differentiate lactose fermenters from non-lactose fermenters.

 

Option D. Sabouraud Dextrose Agar: Incorrect. Sabouraud Dextrose Agar is used for the cultivation of fungi, including yeasts and molds. It is not used to differentiate lactose fermenters from non-lactose fermenters.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MacConkey agar is a selective and differential medium used to distinguish lactose fermenters, which appear as pink colonies, from non-lactose fermenters, which appear as colorless or pale colonies.

questions.text: Which component of the HIV genome is necessary for the virus to enter the host cell membrane? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) GP120

 

GP120 is a glycoprotein on the HIV envelope that binds to the CD4 receptors on host cells. This binding is crucial for the initial attachment of the virus to the host cell, facilitating the subsequent steps that lead to viral entry. GP120 interacts specifically with the CD4 receptor, which is predominantly found on the surface of T-helper cells, macrophages, and dendritic cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. CCR5: CCR5 is a co-receptor on the host cell surface that HIV uses in conjunction with the CD4 receptor to enter the cell. However, it is not a component of the HIV genome but rather a part of the host cell.

 

Option C. GP41: GP41 is another glycoprotein found on the HIV envelope that assists in the fusion of the viral membrane with the host cell membrane after GP120 has bound to the CD4 receptor. It facilitates the entry of the viral core into the host cell cytoplasm.

 

Option D. CXCR4: CXCR4 is another co-receptor used by HIV to enter host cells, particularly in later stages of infection. Like CCR5, it is a part of the host cell and not a component of the viral genome.

 

Educational Objective:


GP120, a glycoprotein on the HIV envelope, is necessary for binding to CD4 receptors on host cells, facilitating viral entry.

questions.text:
Which of the following are acid-fast staining organisms? (INICET MAY 2022)

 

  1. Nocardia
  2. Mycobacterium leprae
  3. Actinomyces
  4. Cryptosporidium parvum
  5. Isospora belli
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2, 4, 5

 

Nocardia, Mycobacterium leprae, Cryptosporidium parvum, and Cystoisospora belli (Options 1, 2, 4, and 5) are acid-fast staining organisms.

 

Acid-fast staining is based on the principle that tubercle bacilli resist decolorization with acids after staining with aniline dyes. Acid fastness is attributed to the variety of fatty acids, alcohols, and lipids in the tubercle bacilli. Acid-fast organisms usually contain mycolic acid, which is acid-fast in the free state. The steps to carry out acid-fast staining as modified by Ziehl and Nelson are:

 

  1. The slide is stained with carbolfuchsin along with the application of heat.
  2. It is then decolorized with 20% sulphuric acid. Later methylene blue is used for counterstaining.
  3. The acid-fast bacteria retain the fuchsin color, while other organisms take up the counterstain.

 

The genus Nocardia are aerobic organisms and weakly acid-fast positive rods. They stain with carbolfuchsin and retain it when 1-4% sulfuric acid is used.

 

Other Option

 

3. Actinomyces: Actinomyces is not an acid-fast organism. They are gram-positive bacteria that are known for forming filamentous structures similar to fungi but do not retain the acid-fast stain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nocardia, Mycobacterium leprae, Cryptosporidium parvum, and Isospora belli are acid-fast staining organisms.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male patient presented to the outpatient department with cervical lymphadenopathy. As a part of the evaluation, the Paul-Bunnell test was done. What is the principle of this test? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Heterophile antibodies

 

The principle of the Paul-Bunnell test is based on heterophile antibodies.

 

Heterophile antibodies agglutinate shared antigens.

 

Paul-Bunnell test is used diagnosing for infectious mononucleosis, wherein heterophile antibodies agglutinate sheep erythrocytes.

 

The Weil-Felix reaction is another example heterophile agglutination test. Here the common antigen is shared between typhus rickettsia and some strains of proteus bacilli. It is helpful in the serodiagnosis of typhus fevers.

 

Streptococcus MG agglutination test for primary atypical pneumonia and the cold agglutination test for mycoplasma (primary atypical) pneumonia are also based on heterophile antibody.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Complement fixation: Incorrect: The complement fixation test is based on the ability of antigen-antibody complexes to fix complement. This is a different mechanism from the heterophile antibody agglutination used in the Paul-Bunnell test.

 

Option B. Super-antigens: Incorrect: Superantigens are a class of antigens that cause excessive activation of the immune system by non-specific activation of T-cells, leading to massive cytokine release. This is not related to the Paul-Bunnell test.

 

Option D. Haptens: Incorrect: Haptens are small molecules that elicit an immune response only when attached to a large carrier such as a protein. The Paul-Bunnell test does not involve haptens.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Paul-Bunnell test is based on the detection of heterophile antibodies, which agglutinate sheep erythrocytes, and is used in the diagnosis of infectious mononucleosis.

choices.text: Direct spread from mesenteric lymph nodes

questions.text: Mode of transmission of abdominal TB includes all except? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Direct contact with infected animal

 

Direct contact with infected animal is not a known mode of transmission for abdominal TB. Tuberculosis is primarily transmitted via inhalation of airborne droplets from a person with active pulmonary TB. While ingestion of Mycobacterium bovis from unpasteurized milk can lead to abdominal TB, Making it a feco-oral route of spread.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Direct spread from mesenteric lymph nodes: This occurs when TB bacteria spread directly from the mesenteric lymph nodes to the intestines. This form of spread is relatively common in abdominal TB.

 

Option C. Feco-oral route: Ingestion of Mycobacterium tuberculosis (from contaminated sputum or unpasteurized milk with M. bovis) can lead to intestinal TB.

 

Option D. Direct contact with infected animal: This is less common but can occur in cases where humans come into contact with animals infected with Mycobacterium bovis, a zoonotic strain of TB.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Modes of spread:

 

  1. By ingesting
    1. Infected food or milk - Primary intestinal tuberculosis
    2. Infected sputum - Secondary intestinal tuberculosis
  2. Hematogenous spread from distant tubercular focus
  3. Contagious spread from infected adjacent foci
  4. Through lymphatic channel
  5. Common site of abdominal TB - Terminal ileum and cecum

 

Feco-oral route is not known to spread abdominal TB.

questions.text: A group of 20 friends kept partying till late at night. Two of them ate pastries from outside. They present with nausea and vomiting in the early morning. What is the most likely causative agent implicated? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Enterotoxin of Staphylococcus

 

The most likely causative agent in the given scenario is enterotoxin of Staphylococcus aureus. It causes food poisoning within 30 minutes to 6 hours after consumption of the contaminated food.

 

The common sources of infection are the foods that are not cooked after handling. These include sliced meats, puddings, pastries, and sandwiches. Patients present with nausea, vomiting, stomach cramps, and diarrhea.

 

Food poisoning is caused by enterotoxin produced by S. aureus. It is a preformed toxin that is relatively heat stable while most of the other exotoxins are heat-labile. It stimulates the vagus nerve and vomiting center of the brain and also stimulates intestinal peristaltic activity. Eight antigenic types of enterotoxin are currently known of which is Type A toxin is responsible for most cases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Emetic toxin of B. cereus: Food poisoning after consumption of fried rice or chinese street food is strongly suggestive of Bacillus cereus (Serotypes 1, 3, 5). Two mechanisms of action have been described for the enterotoxin of B. cereus, one involving stimulation of the cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP) system and the other independent of it. Food poisoning after eating food contaminated with Bacillus cereus is of two types, namely diarrheal type and emetic type, caused by an enterotoxin and an emetic toxin respectively.

 

Option C. Verocytotoxin from E. coli: Associated with a different set of symptoms primarily involving severe abdominal cramps and bloody diarrhea, not rapid-onset vomiting.

 

Option D. Shiga toxin from Shigella: Causes dysentery, which is characterized by fever, abdominal pain, and bloody diarrhea, not primarily vomiting.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The enterotoxin of Staphylococcus aureus can cause rapid-onset food poisoning characterized by nausea and vomiting, typically within hours after consuming contaminated food such as pastries. Remembering the association between specific foods and pathogens can aid in prompt diagnosis and management.

choices.text: The reticulate body is the infectious form.
The elementary body shows metabolic activity.
The reticulate body exists solely intracellularly.
The elementary body is the form that replicates.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Chlamydia Trachomatis is accurate? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. The reticulate body exists solely intracellularly.

 

Explanation:

 

The reticulate body (RB) of Chlamydia trachomatis exists exclusively as an intracellular form. RBs represent the metabolically active, replicative stage of the chlamydial life cycle that can only survive within host cells. After the infectious elementary body enters the host cell, it transforms into the reticulate body which then multiplies by binary fission within a membrane-bound vacuole called an inclusion body. The RB cannot survive in the extracellular environment due to its fragile cell wall and dependency on host cell resources.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The reticulate body is the infectious form - This is incorrect because the elementary body (EB), not the reticulate body, is the infectious form of Chlamydia trachomatis. The EB is the extracellular, metabolically inactive form that is specialized for transmission between cells and hosts. It has a rigid cell wall that enables it to survive in the harsh extracellular environment.

 

Option B. The elementary body shows metabolic activity - This is incorrect because the elementary body is metabolically inactive. EBs are described as the "extracellular and infective form" that only become metabolically active after transforming into reticulate bodies inside host cells.

 

Option D. The elementary body is the form that replicates - This is incorrect because replication is exclusive to the reticulate body form. The life cycle clearly shows that RBs, not EBs, are the "replicative form" that divides by binary fission within host cells. Elementary bodies cannot replicate and must first transform into reticulate bodies for multiplication to occur.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Chlamydia trachomatis has a biphasic life cycle with the metabolically active reticulate body (RB) existing exclusively intracellularly where it replicates, while the environmentally resistant elementary body (EB) serves as the infectious, extracellular form that cannot replicate until it transforms into an RB inside a host cell.

questions.text: Granuloma inguinale is caused by? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Klebsiella granulomatis

 

  • ﻿﻿Granuloma inguinale(donovanosis) is caused by: Calymmatobacterium granulomatis (gram-negative bacillus)
  • Clinically - well-defined, single or multiple, painless ulcers with beefy and red granulation tissue at the base and elevated, rolled, serpiginous, or hyperplastic borders form the primary lesion. The ulcer may heal with prominent fibrosis. Lymphedema with eventual elephantiasis of the penis and scrotum can result in chronic disease. Subcutaneous nodules (pseudobuboes) can simulate lymph node involvement. Lesions may be nodular, hypertrophic, cicatricial, and ulcerovegetative.

 

 

  • Microscopically - there is prominent granulation-type tissue with an inflammatory infiltrate including plasma cells, neutrophils, and histiocytes that contain 0.6- to 2-µm Donovan bodies, which are encapsulated rods with bipolar granules. Pseudoepitheliomatous hyperplasia may be prominent. The gram-negative coccoid to bacillary bacteria may be difficult to identify, requiring Wright/Giemsa, toluidine blue, or Warthin-Starry stains.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. T. pallidum: Treponema pallidum is the causative agent of syphilis, which presents with primary, secondary, and tertiary stages, including painless chancre and systemic manifestations.

 

Option B. Chlamydia: Chlamydia trachomatis is responsible for various conditions, including trachoma, lymphogranuloma venereum, and nongonococcal urethritis, but not granuloma inguinale.

 

Option C. Herpes simplex: Herpes simplex virus causes genital herpes, characterized by painful vesicular and ulcerative lesions on the genitalia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Granuloma inguinale (donovanosis) is caused by Klebsiella granulomatis. It presents with painless ulcers and characteristic beefy red granulation tissue. Diagnosis may require special staining techniques to identify Donovan bodies.
